item.title: Can the Dublin III Regulation strengthen family reunification? The CJEU's ruling on the ability to appeal denials of take charge requests.
item.description: Mark Klaassen, Leiden University Photo credit: DFID Unaccompanied minors can appeal a receiving EU member state’s denial of a request to assume responsibility for their asylum case. This conclusion from the Court of Justice of the EU (CJEU) comes from its judgment in the I. & S. case. Interestingly, the District Court of Haarlem in the Netherlands initially posed the question because the Dublin III Regulation, which governs such transfers, doesn’t explicitly provide for this appeal right.

item.title: Love triumphs in the CJEU: Equal Marriage and EU Freedom of Movement Legislation

item.title: The CJEU ruling on domestic violence and the free movement of EU citizens is disgraceful.
item.description: Steve Peers EU freedom of movement laws don’t directly apply to non-EU citizens. Instead, they gain rights through family ties with EU citizens. This poses a problem in domestic violence situations where the abuser is an EU citizen and the victim is not. Leaving the abuser could lead to expulsion, forcing victims to choose between their safety and remaining in the country, potentially separated from their children. EU law attempts to mitigate this risk.
